DOC.P: Number of levels in this building block according to the global tiling scheme. The default value is 14, for levels 0..13.
List of level headers. levelHeader[i] is the header for level i. An empty level i has a header with each value set to 0.
List of level data. levels[i] is the data for level i. The level depends on the level header at the corresponding index position.
Top level type of the Basic Map Display Building Block.
List of tiles for a given level. The length of the list is indicated by the level header.
The content of each level is a list of tiles.
Minimum recommended map scale (1 : scaleMin) for the current level.
Minimum recommended map scale (1 : scaleMax) for the current level.
Number of subscales for this level.
Subscale values for this level. The values are between scaleMin and scaleMax and must be in ascending order.

If a feature has the subscale attribute i in the range 0..numSubscales, the rendering engine should suppress this feature if the map scale is less than subscale[i-1]. Thus, a feature with subscale index 0 will never be suppressed.
All coordinate values in this level are to be shifted by coordShift bits, i.e. to be multiplied by 2^coordShift.
Number of tiles in this level.
The level header contains information that applies to all tiles of the given level.
Header information, valid for all features.
Map features and attributes.
A tile is composed of header information and a list of map features.
Tile id according to the global tiling scheme.
Default coordinate width for this tile.
Compression method to be used in this tile.
Offset of attribute table from start of tile.
Size of attribute table.
Header for a tile with data relevant to all features in that tile.
Number of area features.
List of area features.
Number of area features.
List of line features.
Number of point features.
List of point features.
Attribute table for the current tile.
Tile content for a given tile, identified by the header.
DOC.PARAM: header header data for the current tile

DOC.P: No compression.
The compression method is indicated per feature.
Indicates the bit-level compression methods to be applied to coordinates of features in the current tile.
8 bit coordinate offsets.
12 bit coordinate offsets.
16 bit coordinate offsets.
24 bit coordinate offsets.
Absolute coordinates as int32.

Default number of bits used for coordinate encoding in this tile. Coordinates are specified as (positive) offsets relative to the southwest corner of the tile, except for COORD_WIDTH_32, where absolute values are used.
Point feature types.

DOC.P: Line feature types.
DOC.TODO: Assign values. The value sets for point, line and area feature types must be disjoint.

DOC.P: Area feature types.
DOC.TODO: Assign values. The value sets for point, line and area feature types must be disjoint.

DOC.P: Number of vertices of the area feature. This is the total number for all faces. The number of vertices per face is not encoded explicitly. For numbers larger than 15, this value is set to 1, and the actual number of vertices is encoded in the optional field extNumVertices.
Scale sublevel for this feature.
Administrative level of this area.
Method for obtaining the name for this feature.
Additional data for obtaining the name for this feature.
Extended number of vertices. This field is present only if the feature has more than 15 vertices.
Compressed list of vertex coordinates. The default coordinate width and the actual number of vertices are passed to the child type.

An area feature has a geometry that may be composed of multiple faces. The total number of vertices is 3 or more. Faces are not modelled explicitly as datatypes. A face is simply a list of successive vertices. The face category and the last vertex of each face are indicated by flags.
The encoding method for coordinates of this feature.
Number of bits to be used for coordinate encoding.
Anchor point for the current area feature. In general, this point is not a vertex of the polygon. It should be the south-west vertex of the bounding rectangle.
Uncompressed encoding with tile dependent width.
Compressed encoding with feature dependent width.
Compressed difference encoding with feature dependent width.
List of vertices in a variety of encodings.
Compressed list of vertex coordinates for an area feature.

Each polygon is specified by an ordered sequence of at least 3 vertices. For the last vertex of a polygon, the polygonFlag of this vertex is 1. The total number of vertices in all polygons is a parameter of this type. The number of vertices per polygon can be derived from the polygon flag.
The polygonFlag of the first two vertices determine the polygon type. type = 2*v0.polygonFlag + v1.polygonFlag.
All polygons shall have positive orientation. In the (x,y) plane, positive orientation is counter-clockwise, e.g. (0,0), (1,0), (0,1).
(Orientation is important for surfaces embedded into 3D space to distinguish front and back, or inside and outside. Any face of a polyhedron shall have positive orientation seen from the outside.)
Let v0, v1, v2, ..., vk be the sequence of vertices.
Convex polygon:
The edges of the polygon are (v0, v1), (v1, v2), ..., (vk-1, vk), (vk, v0).
vi.isPseudoEdge == true indicates that (vi, vi+1) is a pseudo-edge, where vk+1 is identified with v0.
Triangle strip:
A triangle strip is composed of k-1 triangles (v0, v1, v2), (v2, v1, v3), (v3, v4, v5), (v5, v4, v6) and so on.
Each of these triangles has positive orientation due to the reversed vertex order in every other triangle.
The edges (v1, v2), (v2, v3), ..., (vk-2, vk-1) are pseudo-edges by construction.
vi.isPseudoEdge indicates that the following edge is a pseudo-edge:
(v0, v1) for i = 0 (vk-1, vk) for i = k (vi-1, vi+1) otherwise
Triangle fan:
A triangle fan is composed of k-1 triangles (v0, v1, v2), (v0, v2, v3), (v0, v3, v4), and so on.
Each of these triangles has positive orientation.
The edges (v0, v2), (v0, v3), ..., (v0, vk-1) are pseudo-edges by construction.
vi.isPseudoEdge indicates that the following edge is a pseudo-edge:
(vi, vi+1) for i < k (vk, v0) for i = k
Relative and absolute coordinates

In general, vertex coordinates are relative to the anchor point. The anchor point coordinates are relative to the south-west tile corner. Within the tile, coordinates are shifted by coordShift as indicated in the LevelHeader.
All in all, we have
abs.x = corner.x + ((anchor.x + v.x) << coordShift) abx.y = corner.y + ((anchor.y + v.y) << coordShift)
If header.coordWidth == COORD_WIDTH_32, the anchor coordinates are absolute, so that
abs.x = anchor.x + (v.x << coordShift) abs.y = anchor.y + (v.y << coordShift)
The geometry of each area feature is decomposed into multiple polygons. The type of each polygon is indicated by following values.
Note that the value is not encoded in one place; it is derived from the polygonFlag of the first two vertices of each polygon.
x coordinate (longitude).
y coordinate (latitude).
If true, the edge associated to this vertex is a pseudo-edge. The assocication depends on the polygon type.
Indicates the polygon type and the last vertex of a polygon.
Explicit encoding of vertex coordinates. All coordinates are positive offsets with respect to the anchor point defined in AreaCoordXY.
Number of bits for x coordinates.
Number of bits for y coordinates.
x coordinate of first vertex v0.
y coordinate of first vertex v0.
If true, the edge associated to this vertex is a pseudo-edge. The assocication depends on the polygon type.
Indicates the polygon type and the last vertex of a polygon.
Remaining vertices v[1], ..., v[numVertices-1].
Vertex list of an area feature with difference encoding of coordinates.
DOC.PARAM: numBits number of bits for the coordinates of the first vertex

DOC.P: Sign of x coordinate difference.
Absolute value of x coordinate difference.
Sign of y coordinate difference.
Absolute value of y coordinate difference.
If true, the edge associated to this vertex is a pseudo-edge. The assocication depends on the polygon type.
Indicates the polygon type and the last vertex of a polygon.
Remaining vertices of an area feature in difference encoding.
The vertex coordinates relative to the anchor are defined recursively by
v[i].x = v[i-1].x + (1-2*signX) * dx v[i].y = v[i-1].y + (1-2*signY) * dy
DOC.TODO: When DataScript support signed and unsigned bitfields, we can replace each pair of sign and absolute value by a single signed value.

DOC.P: Feature has the same name as the previous one.
Feature has no name at all.
Name reference for this feature can be obtained by adding the following value to the name reference of the previous feature.
Name reference follows.
Method for obtaining a name reference for the current feature.
Offset with respect to previous name reference. (May be negative!)
Explicit name reference.
Additional data for obtaining a name reference.
DOC.PARAM: source method for obtaining a name reference.

DOC.P: Feature has the same attribute values as the previous one.
The following uint8 is an index into the attribute table, the attribute can be read from table[index].
The following uint16 is an index into the attribute table, the attribute can be read from table[index].
The following uint32 is the attribute value.
Method for obtaining the attribute values for this feature.
Index into attribute table.
Index into attribute table.
Explicit attribute value.
Additional data for obtaining the attribute values for the current feature.
Optional container for storing the number of vertices of a feature, when this number is too large for 4 bits.
Number of vertices of this feature. If the actual number is larger than 15, this value is set to 1 and the actual number is stored in extNumVx.
Method for obtaining the attributes.
Method for obtaining a name reference.
Additional data for obtaining the attributes.
Additional data for obtaining a name reference.
Optional field to be used if the number of vertices is larger than 15. In this case, numVertices is set to 1, and this field must be present.
List of vertices for this line feature.

A line feature has a geometry that is specified as a sequence of points. Unlike area features, line features may have z coordinates that indicate the altitude or at least a relative position of features ("z level").
To reduce the data size, the attributes are factored out into a separate table.
Attribute values.
Attribute table for features in a tile. The attributes for a feature are read from a given index in this table. This assumes that the attributes all fit within 32 bits.
No speed limit.
Speed limit 130 km/h.
Speed limit 100 km/h.
Speed limit 90 km/h.
Speed limit 70 km/h.
Speed limit 50 km/h.
Speed limit 30 km/h.
Speed limit 10 km/h.
Speed category for road features.
For properties that depend on the direction of a line feature, this type indicates for which of the two directions the property is true.
The positive direction is starting from vertex 0 toward vertex n-1.
Attributes for road features.
Coordinates are specified separately for each vertex.
Coordinates are specified as differences to the predecessor.
Special encoding for the 2 vertices of a straight line segment.
Method for coordinate encoding.
The feature has no z-coordinates.
The z-coordinates are z-levels (i.e. very small positive or negative integers), indicating the relative height of features.
The z-level indicates the height in meters.
DOC.TODO: Height above ground or absolute height?

DOC.P: Type of z-coordinates for a line feature.
Encoding method for x and y coordinates.
Number of bits for each coordinate.
Anchor point for the current line feature. In general, this point is not a vertex of the feature. It should be the south-west vertex of the bounding rectangle.
Separate encoding of vertices.
Difference encoding of vertices.
Compact encoding of a line with 2 points
List of vertices in a variety of encodings.
Type of z coordinates.
List of z coordinates.
Coordinates of a line feature. In contrast to area features, a line feature may have z-coordinates in addition to x and y-coordinates.
Pair of x,y coordinates with a given width.
DOC.PARAM: numBits number of bits for coordinate encoding

DOC.P: Number of bits for x coordinates.
Number of bits for y coordinates.
x coordinate of first vertex v0.
y coordinate of first vertex v0.
List of coordinates for remaining vertices.
Vertex list of a line feature with difference encoding of coordinates.
DOC.PARAM: numBits number of bits for the coordinates of the first vertex

DOC.P: Sign of x coordinate difference.
Absolute value of x coordinate difference.
Sign of y coordinate difference.
Absolute value of y coordinate difference.
Remaining vertices of a line feature in difference encoding.
The vertex coordinates relative to the anchor are defined recursively by
v[i].x = v[i-1].x + (1-2*signX) * dx v[i].y = v[i-1].y + (1-2*signY) * dy
DOC.PARAM: nx number of bits for x coordinates
ny number of bits for y coordinates
DOC.TODO: When DataScript support signed and unsigned bitfields, we can replace each pair of sign and absolute value by a single signed value.

DOC.P: Width of bounding rectangle.
Height of bounding rectangle.
Selects one of the two diagonals.
Compact encoding of a line feature with 2 vertices with respect to the anchor point.
The anchor is the south-west corner of the bounding rectangle of the line. The vector (dx, dy) rooted at this anchor defines the north-east corner of this rectangle.
The line is then the south-west to north-east diagonal of the rectangle, or the north-west to south-east diagonal, if flip == 1.
flip == 0: v[0].x = anchor.x v[1].x = anchor.x + dx v[0].y = anchor.y v[1].y = anchor.y + dy
flip == 1: v[0].x = anchor.x v[1].x = anchor.x + dx v[0].y = anchor.y + dy v[1].y = anchor.y
DOC.TODO: Do we need another flag for the direction?

DOC.P: Type of point feature.
Attributes of point feature.
Name reference.
(x,y) coordinates.

Point feature with a single vertex, attributes and a name reference. Since the attributes fit into 8 bits in most cases, we do not use a reference into the attribute table as with lines and areas. Since point features rarely share a name, we specify the name reference directly.
Attributes of point feature. When adminLevel is not present, a default value of CAPITAL_NO is assumed, i.e. the city is not a capital of any administrative region.
City is not a capital.
City is a capital or order 1 admin area.
City is a capital or order 2 admin area.
City is a capital or order 3 admin area.
City is a capital or order 4 admin area.
City is a capital or order 5 admin area.
City is a capital or order 6 admin area.
City is a capital or order 7 admin area.
Less than 5000.
5000 <= population < 10000
10000 <= population < 50000
50000 <= population < 100000
100000 <= population < 500000
500000 <= population < 1 million
1 million <= population < 5 million
Population is 5 million or more
Approximate population of a city.
Pair of coordinates with a given width, i.e. number of bits. Unless the width is 32, all coordinates are positive, specifying an offset from an anchor point.
DOC.PARAM: width number of bits per coordinate

DOC.P: Pair of 8 bit coordinates.
Pair of 12 bit coordinates.
Pair of 16 bit coordinates.
Pair of 24 bit coordinates.

Number of bits for each coordinate.
Array for z-coordinates. The z-coordinate at index i belongs to the i-th vertex of the corresponding line feature.

DOC.P: Sequence of z coordinates for a line feature. The coordinates may be negative and are encoded in two's complement.
